column2: Among the people of Hausaland and the region of the great Lake Chad, there is an old faith in which mortals enter communion with eternal spirits. These spiritual forces are known as bori and exist in their own spiritual realm known as Jan Gari, but can be summoned by skilled individuals who offer their bodies for the spirits to possess. With the right ritual, spirits will offer guidance to those who summon them.

A Tat Roog means "The way of the Divine" in the Serer language. Many are the faiths practiced among the peoples of the Western Sahel, but a common pattern resonates among most of them. A supreme creator god, who watches mankind from abode, a primordial set of twins who play a role in creating the world, and a fascination with the Sirius star that guides the destinies of man.

A Tat Roog means "The way of the Divine" in the Serer language. Many are the faiths practiced among the peoples of the Western Sahel, but a common pattern resonates among most of them. A supreme creator god, who watches mankind from abode, a primordial set of twins who play a role in creating the world, and a fascination with the Sirius star that guides the destinies of man.

Many are the gods worshiped by the Berbers through their history. At one time or another they prayed to the old gods of Egypt and Phoenicia, or even Greece and Rome. But they also prayed to gods of their own making, and made others pray to them as well, from Numidia to old Carthage.

Many are the gods worshiped by the Berbers through their history. At one time or another they prayed to the old gods of Egypt and Phoenicia, or even Greece and Rome. But they also prayed to gods of their own making, and made others pray to them as well, from Numidia to old Carthage.
The Church of the Amazigh People
The person that this title is bestowed upon is considered to be the Champion of the Realm. There is surely no greater honor for mortal men to aspire to.
column3: La personne à qui ce titre est décerné est considérée comme le champion du royaume. Aucun mortel ne saurait espérer titre plus honorable.
column4: Die Person, die diesen Titel erhalten hat, wird als Champion des Reiches angesehen. Es gibt wahrlich keine größere Ehre für Sterbliche.
column6: La persona a la que se le otorga este título es considerada como el Campeón del Reino. No se puede aspirar a un honor mayor para los hombres mortales.

column2: The Master of the Blade is a prestigious honorific usually granted to those with demonstrated ability in swordsmanship.
column3: Le maître de la lame est un titre prestigieux habituellement décerné à ceux qui ont démontré leur habileté à manier l'épée.
column4: Der Meister des Schwertes ist eine prestigeträchtige Ehrung, die nur den Erfahrensten im Umgang mit dem Schwert zuteil wird.
column6: El Maestro de la Espada es un prestigioso título honorífico concedido a aquellas personas con demostrada capacidad en el manejo de la espada.

column2: The Master of the Bow is a prestigious honorific usually granted to those with demonstrated ability in bowmanship.
column3: Le maître de l'arc est un titre prestigieux habituellement décerné à ceux qui ont démontré leur habileté à manier l'arc.
column4: Der Meister des Bogens ist eine prestigeträchtige Ehrung, die nur den Erfahrensten im Umgang mit dem Bogen zuteil wird.
column6: El Maestro del Arco es un prestigioso título honorífico concedido a aquellas personas con demostrada capacidad en el manejo del Arco.

column2: This honorific can only be granted to those who have reached the age of fifty. Their wisdom and the sorely needed guidance they offer the younger generations is deserving of great respect.
column3: Ce titre honorifique ne peut être accordé qu'à ceux qui ont atteint l'âge de cinquante ans. Leur sagesse et leurs conseils, dont ont grandement besoin les générations plus jeunes, appellent à un grand respect.
column4: Diese Ehrung können nur jene erhalten, die das fünfzigste Lebensjahr erreicht haben. Ihre Weisheit und ihr dringend benötigter Rat für jüngere Generationen verdienen den höchstmöglichen Respekt.
column6: Este título honorífico sólo puede concederse a quienes hayan alcanzado la edad de cincuenta. Su sabiduría y la muy necesaria guía que ofrecen a las nuevas generaciones se merecen un gran respeto.

column2: The Magajiya Yaljigari is a trusted woman who is in charge of informing the ruler of the news around the capital.
A griot is a historian, a storyteller and a poet. A very trusted position in any West African court.
The chiroma is the traditional title held by the heir apparent in the lands of Kanem. Holding it may be enough to persuade the court to back the candidate in the eventual succession.
Bayajidda was a Baghdadi prince who was exiled to Africa. After reaching Hausaland, he gained the locals' favor by killing the monstrous snake Sarki.
Daurama was a great matriarch of the Hausa people. She ruled as a celibate religious leader but broke her vows to marry the hero Bayajidda as a reward for his bravery.
Born into slavery, Bilal was the son of an exiled Ethiopian princess. After befriending the prophet Muhammad he became the first muezzin in islamic history.
Prince Mari-Djata was born disabled and exiled from Niani by his jealous stepmother. However, he would return to reclaim his birthright, becoming the first Mansa of Mali.
Set was a leader of the Zaghawa people, who left the nomadic lifestyle of his nation and founded the city of Djimi, governing as the first ruler of the Duguwa dynasty.
[This.GetTitledNameWithNick] was the magnificent ruler who presided over the rebirth of the Carthaginian Empire from the very ashes.
the ancient spiritual traditions of the Western Sahel have been unified into a single and true way of the divine, capable of resisting any foreign incursion.
the faith of Carthage and Numidia will return the old gods to their place of honor and liberate the people of North Africa from the Abrahamic yoke.
Ancestors can now be beatified and canonized
Your §YGriot§! has §YLearning§! greater than or equal to 12
African Great Holy Wars are unlocked
[From.GetSheHeCap] has the wisdom of a bori spirit who has possessed [From.GetHerHim]
The bori spirit possessing my liege surely knows best
[From.GetSheHeCap] is the §YChiroma§!, the position traditionally held by the heir apparent

The §YChristian§! world is outraged by your actions.\nThe destruction of the city and the §YHoly See§! has gravely affected the §YMoral Authority§! of the §YCatholic Church§!, as well as the faith of Rome's former owner.\nYou loot §Y2000§! gold from the city.

The §YChristian§! world is outraged by your actions.\nThe destruction of the city has gravely affected the §YMoral Authority§! of the §YOrthodox Church§!, as well as the faith of Constantinople's former owner.\nYou loot §Y2000§! gold from the city.

The §YAmazigh§! world is outraged by your actions.\nThe destruction of the city has gravely affected the §YMoral Authority§! of the §YChurch of the Amazigh People§!.\nYou loot §Y2000§! gold from the city.
In order to edify the faith we shall unify the many traditions of life and divination practiced by the different nations of the land.
As the heirs of an antique land we must revive all the customs practiced by the kings of Carthage and Numidia.
The Inna, our spiritual mother, deserves the loving protection of a faithful ruler. As her liege I shall provide that protection.
For too long our spiritual mother, the Inna, has seen her power limited by secular rulers. We must grant her full religious sovereignty, which will bring prosperity and glory to our realms.
During Awussu's heat wave the festival of the same name is celebrated. It is a tradition that dates back to the Phoenician times.
Long ago the great Carthaginian empire perished under the Roman sword. The time has come to see its glory reborn.

There are many gods and goddesses who rule over different aspects of our life. While all of them should be honored properly, it is common for people to pick a deity whom they pray and sacrifice to more often.
It is good to have a protective spirit, therefore it would be a good idea to choose one.

In your court as well as among the common people, gossips say that you do not deserve your titles. After all, a person of your ancestry is not made to occupy such a position. Only prejudices and superstitions, certainly, but enough for people to speak ill of you.\n\nYour Court Griot, however proposes a solution - he will compose a great poem in which he will say that all your ancestors were in fact of the correct caste. A little fib for the greater good.

In your court as well as among the common people, gossips say that you do not deserve your titles. After all, a person of your ancestry is not made to occupy such a position. Only prejudices and superstitions, certainly, but enough for people to speak ill of you.\n\nYou will need the advice of a learned Court Griot.
The §YBori§! pilgrims that flock to the holy site in §Y[Root.Location.GetName]§! impress me with the depth and passion of their faith. I am tempted to convert in secrecy...
Secretly Convert to A Tat Roog

The §YAmazigh§! pilgrims that flock to the holy site in §Y[Root.Location.GetName]§! impress me with the depth and passion of their faith. I am tempted to convert in secrecy...
The Yan Riga, those who wear clothes, are the most civilized spirits. It is said that they live in cities and know about the wisdom of men who can read. Their king is Mallam Alhaji.
The Babbaku, that is, the black ones, are inhabitants of rural villages. Some are farmers and other hunters. Their king is Mai-Ja-Ciki.
The Tan Garki, that is, the sons of the shield, are the great warriors among the spirits. Their king is Garki Baba.
Samari, the spirits of youth but also of femininity. It's a very colorful group. Their king is Ba-Gudu.
The Yayan Zanzanna, the children of the plague, are child spirits with dominion over any disease, spreading smallpox and other evils among mortals, Their queen is Nana Mariyamu.
The Tan Dowa are spirits of the jungle, they do not resemble any juman but are nature in its purest state. Zaki the lion is the first among them.
In secret, the faithful have organized around a small church community in this province. From there it converts others, grows, and protects their own.
In secret, the faithful have organized around a small church community in this province. From there it converts others, grows, and protects their own.

This character, though not a worshipper of the African gods, has a special sympathy and understanding for the African faiths and their practitioners.
This character belongs to the Foro caste, the West African caste of rulers and landowners.
This character belongs to the Jakhanke caste, the West African caste of religious scholars and educators.
This character belongs to the Wangara caste, the West African caste of merchants and traders.
This character has fought in a great holy war while possessed by warrior bori.
This character has fought in a great holy war in the name of Roog the merciful.
This character has fought for the Amazigh faith as Queen Dihya did in the days of yore.
This character is the highest magistrate of the Carthaginian Empire.
The lost territory of the Carthaginian Empire must be reclaimed! §Y$CLAIMANT$§! can use this Casus Belli to seize all titles held by §Y$TARGET$§! within the de jure §Y$TITLE$§!.
This casus belli allows §Y$CLAIMANT$§! to declare war on the old imperial nemesis controlled by §Y$TARGET$§! to annex all conquered land and completely destroy their mighty metropolis.

With the arrival of new faiths, the traditional followers of the bori spirits have seen the old ways threatened. However, despite the displacement, people still speak of those living in the outskirts of society, practicing secret ceremonies in which ancient specters are summoned.  These are the Maguzawa, as they are called by the unfaithful.

While some preach the word of the creator in the open, others do so in the shadows. Seeing themselves as the keepers of the one true god, there are followers of Roog who refuse to give up their faith in the face of any adversity and in secret continue whispering songs in the Sigui So tongue. After all, the Yoonir start shine better on those who seek the protection of the night.

While some preach the word of the creator in the open, others do so in the shadows. Seeing themselves as the keepers of the one true god, there are followers of Roog who refuse to give up their faith in the face of any adversity and in secret continue whispering songs in the Sigui So tongue. After all, the Yoonir start shine better on those who seek the protection of the night.

Many have tried to steal the Amazigh faith away from its believers. In bygone eras the temples of Tanit stood magnificent and proud all over the Mediterranean, only to be consumed by the flames of persecution. For these reasons, there are those who seek to preserve the faith in secret, hoping that in the desert nights the old tales will survive safe from those who wish to destroy them.
